prompt:
Guidelines: Read the text in full, searching for the following information: 1. Key Terms and Definitions: Search for any terms defined by the author to clarify their point or useful terminology found in the text essential to the author's argument. If no definitions are found, skip writing about them. 2. Research Fundamentals: Focus on extracting and understanding its core research elements, including the central research problem, core research questions, and the corresponding hypotheses. Each element should be identified and discussed in relation to the content of the document. 3. Key Findings: Identify its key findings. Concentrate on presenting a detailed analysis of these findings, outlining the main conclusions drawn by the authors within the study. For each finding, provide a clear explanation that encapsulates the essence of the discovery or conclusion, and include multiple direct quotes from the document that illustrate or support these findings. **Important Notes:** - every paragraph should be referenced with direct citations from the document or paraphrased and referenced. - Everything should be supported by your reading. If no information is found, do not make it up. - Do not write unsupported statements. - The text should be academic, concise, objective, coherent, and cohesive, using linking/transitioning words. - Include real citations from the document, specifying the author, year, and page number where the information can be found. **Example HTML Structure for the Summary:** ```html

[search for all definitions in the text if any or skip it]

[explain the paper's research type and its objectives]

[explain the paper's research problem, what is the object of the research, and why it is relevant]

[go through some central research questions of the author and how they interact with the research problem]

[explain how the hypothesis of the author interacts with the research question and the problem, meaning what the author proposes to address the research problem and respond to the research questions]

[cite and explain two findings found in the paper related to the research problem and the subject, including direct citations with author, year, and page number]

```

Guidelines: Read the text in full, searching for the following information: 1. Shortcomings and Limitations: Identify and elucidate the document's shortcomings and limitations. Search throughout the text to gather all information and present it as a summary. Each identified shortcoming should be clearly explained and substantiated with multiple direct quotes. Highlight important parts in bold. 2. Research Gaps and Future Research Directions: Extract and articulate the research gaps identified by the author(s) and the suggested future research directions. This analysis should cover the areas the study has not explored or fully addressed, highlighting opportunities for further investigation. Each identified research gap and proposed direction for future research should be clearly explained and, where possible, supported by direct quotes from the document. **Important Notes:** - Paragraphs should be mostly referenced with direct citations from the document or paraphrased and referenced. - Everything should be supported by your reading. - For every subject discussed, provide at least two examples with references. If no information is found, do not make it up. - Do not write unsupported statements. - The text should be academic, concise, objective, coherent, and cohesive, using linking/transitioning words. - Include real citations from the document, specifying the author, year, and page number where the information can be found. **Example HTML Structure for the Summary:** ```html

[explain the two shortcoming found in the text, supported by direct quotes]

[identify and explain the two research gap in the text, supported by direct quotes]

  • [propose research questions for future research if easily two find in the text]
    • ```

Guidelines: Read the text in full, searching for the following information: 1. Data Collection Techniques: Identify and explain the data collection techniques used in the study. Discuss the sampling techniques, data collection instruments, and measurement tools. Provide at least two examples with references. 2. Data Analysis: Identify and explain the data analysis methods used in the study. Discuss quantitative, qualitative, and mixed-methods analysis as applicable. Provide at least two examples with references. 3. Theoretical Frameworks or Models: Identify and articulate the theoretical frameworks and models that underlie the research. Provide explanations based on the document's content, supplemented by direct quotes as evidence of these theoretical/model orientations. Provide at least two examples with references. **Important Notes:** - Paragraphs should be mostly referenced with direct citations from the document or paraphrased and referenced. - Everything should be supported by your reading. - For every subject discussed, provide at least two examples with references. If no information is found, do not make it up. - Do not write unsupported statements. - If no clear data, analysis, or theoretical frameworks are found, skip it. If none of the three are found, return an empty div. - The text should be academic, concise, objective, coherent, and cohesive, using linking/transitioning words. - Include real citations from the document, specifying the author, year, and page number where the information can be found. **Example HTML Structure for the Summary:** ```html

[explain one data collection technique used in the study, supported by direct quotes if any,If none, skip it]

[identify and explain one data analysis method used in the study, supported by direct quotes if any, If none, skip it]

[explain one theoretical framework or model used in the study, supported by direct quotes. If none, skip it]

[explain another theoretical framework or model used in the study, supported by direct quotes. If none, skip it]

```
